comment: Much better the second time I tried it. Had with ice. Very basic bourbon taste that’s a little sweeter than most. Not offensive and cheap. Needs ice and also a good mixer with ginger ale
A fine mixer, nothing really there to it other than some sweet and oak

Nose: Light floral sweetness and black pepper.
Taste: super light mouth feel, light sweetness and pepper. Not too much heat. A light clean bourbon. Doesn’t blow up my skirt but there is literally nothing bad about it and for around $10 its not too shabby.
A swift peppery and sweet taste
I actually think this stuff is pretty decent. At $10 a fifth, all you've got to lose is $10. Give it a try.
Floral notes are most prominent, with slight pepper spices. Of budget bourbons it's one of the few to have such a strong tendency toward one flavor profile. But it's not the greatest execution.

(2.13.15) This is an old standby for me in mixes but I'm just getting around to a real review. This is very sweet and a touch of sour but pretty mild all around. Ice makes it even milder - I'm afraid I could drink it all night long on a bad night without ever tasting much except a buzz but luckily I just keep it around for a mixer and resealing my barrel for bourbon beer. Too much and you start realizing the earthy/mineral off-flavors in the background.
For the price ($9), this can't be beat. Super smooth. Hardly any Kentucky hug. Finishes with a cherry note that's only slightly too strong for my ideal. Extraordinarily drinkable.
spicey, astringent, pepper, ginger, leather, carnations, sweet burnt wheat, dried cherry, tar
Best bourbon you will find for the money. Probably the best all around for under $25. I use this when entertaining for more traditional bourbon cocktails
A little lighter than Buffalo Trace, but still carries the essence.  Best for cocktails, though.  A little too much gas for sipping.

This bourbon punches above its weight. At $10 it's an incredible value. Skip buying Jack or Jim. It's more interesting, rock solid on, er, the rocks and a great cocktailer. Plus you'll have money left over for therapy lessons after realizing you've been throwing your money away on bigger names.

Color: Very Light Amber-
Nose: Mint, Cigar Boxes, Honey, Tobacco, Orange Zest-
Taste: Apricot, Cherry, Ginger, Pears, Nutmeg, Various Spices-
Finish:  Strong Fruitcake and Dried Fruit Finish, Nice fading burn

Very good Bourbon for the price.  The youth of the Bourbon (~36m) is apparent, but it still packs a very fruity, spicy, nutty punch (especially for an entry priced spirit).  Benchmark manages to deliver its payload without much of the chemical burn typically found in similarly aged (and priced) offerings. The dried fruit finish is very pleasurable. I was very surprised and impressed by this Bourbon, and would highly recommend it.

Without offering my own formal notes, it's worth pointing out that Distiller's tasting notes are way off the mark here: as another user below points out, Benchmark isn't only a) made from Buffalo Trace's #1, low-rye mashbill, b) BT's #1 low-rye mashbill is one of the lowest rye content mashbills used by any bourbon maker, anywhere. Distiller's notes here would make a lot more sense for Ancient Age, which comes from the higher-rye BT #2 mashbill.

My favorite of the budget bourbons. Corn, tobacco and leather on the nose, sweet palate with some citrus (orange peel?) and smooth finish with some more sweetness despite some roughness around the edges. In a blind taste test with friends, this showed well and was favored by all over Jim Beam White... most preferred it over Evan Williams Black, Jack Daniels, and Four Roses Yellow Label.

EDIT: I had posted a comment about recent bottles seeming milder/younger, but it was probably because I was tasting Benchmark after finishing off a handle of 90 proof Ezra Brooks (robust, and not particularly smooth or sweet)... I had Benchmark and Eagle Rare back to back this evening and was shocked at how close the $10 Benchmark came to the $30 Eagle Rare... yes, it lacked some of the ABV, barrel influence, and finish that helps balance Eagle Rare, but was very close and reminded me why I keep buying Benchmark at 1/3 the price!

It is absolutely hilarious to me that this review repeatedly mentions that this bourbon is "high in rye" when the Buffalo Trace mash bill #1 that this is based in has the least rye of any rye flavored bourbon that I know of.
It doesn't have a wide flavor profile, but very smooth, no alcohol heat as it is on 80 proof. I recommend getting a bottle just because of the price of $11 locally.
It's not the most popular, but for the "big 4" cocktails it is the right price and taste.

Nose: Corn and honey in a mellow way with sweet and fruity notes.

Taste: Dry leather and hints of fruity notes.

Finish: Corn mash hits you hard with oak and dry fruity notes.

Balance: Robust and sour but decent dram. People have given it a much higher score than I did so for the price you'll be getting it, it's a good dram.
Great taste for the cost.  It's one of my favorites.  Very light burn and smooth taste. Easy and light on the palette.
Great bang-for-buck ratio here. Good enough to sip, cheap enough to mix without shedding a tear. I keep this puppy in my personal bar at all times.
Good for mixed drinks. Pretty weak due to being cut down to 80 proof, but at 10 bucks a fifth, I keep a bottle around to mix with Coke. Very light and watery neat
Simple bourbon. Nothing special in the spicy sweetness but at $10 it is worthy of the Buffalo Trace trademark.
For under $20, best cheap stuff out there. Slight sweetness, vanilla. Pour a couple bottles in a small oak barrel for 10 days and it's even better!
This was my go-to value pour for a long time. Vanilla, Oak, Citrus with a light oaky bitterness on the finish. I've found that for the same money I actually prefer Ezra Brooks or Virgin 101

Solid for the price. A lot of corn flavor, a bit of harshness, likely the best you can get for $7 but dont believe the buffalo trace hype. It's decent but this definitely shows that everything they touch isnt gold
Very thin on the mouth feel and very sweet. Very short finish and very little burn. Not bad.
I mean, it was $12, but tasted like it was $18.
too sweet, but not bad for the price.
Chalky, tart, under ripe cherries... and a handful of cedar mulch.

Sweet smell when you get past the alcohol smell, and definitely super sweet once it’s in a rocks glass with a few cubes. Probably too sweet for me. So far in my hunt for bottom shelf bliss this is a no go. The ranking of cheap stuff for me is EW black, then Ancient Age, followed by EW green
5 stars because of the price. I mean best bang for the buck out there. I think it's delicious
This bourbon replaced Jim Beam (white label) as my BBQ sauce bourbon.  It is also not a bad "highball" Bourbon as it is simple.  For the price point, you cannot complain.

2.7. Heard this was good, straight from someone who lives and works near the distilleries...  Thats a good enough reason to put this on my wish list... will try it, then decide for myself... I bet I will like it.  After all, I am a  fan of Buffalo Trace...
Best cheap mixing bourbon. None of the harsh aftertaste of other similarly priced cheap bourbons.
Went with this after a tour of the Buffalo Trace Distillery. Very pleasant and basically good to sip on.  Under $10 a bottle and a worthy taste.
Less flavor then buffalo trace but very similar and a lot cheaper.
You really can’t beat the price for a cheap mixer. Solo, has a strong toffee flavor that quickly dissipates and becomes very harsh in the finish.

Benchmark Old No 8 @ 80 proof.   12.99 for 1 Liter
    
    Bottom of the shelf whiskey is bottom shelf whiskey,,,, yes or no?  Well "maybe" is the answer but one thing about these bottles that have been around for many decades, they have staying power for a reason, cheap and dependable if not that great is still delivering value. 
    
    Benchmark is an 80 proofer that drinks like a 90 proof, the black label belies the  content being a mid grade offering yet this bourbons taste has more in common with a black label Beam or Evan than the weaker white and green label brethren.   While there is nothing like a complexity of sweetness and woods or other flavors the bare bones of a bourbon whiskey stand up in notes of pepper carmels and oak just enough to pass as a slightly above bottom shelf white label bourbon. 
    
    The heat and burn are evident in the finish but nothing beyond what the proof would warrant and thus there is little or nothing in the way of negative flavoring to dissuade from follow up drinks.  While you wouldn't want to make Benchmark an every day drinker given what it is,  at the price it is a real value and thus deserving of recognition.
Unfinished taste but not horrible for the price

Color: The color of this Buffalo Trace product is a polished mahogany wood.

Nose: The nose has basic notes of caramel, vanilla, and oak, but it also boasts unique subtleties like sour gummy worms and pine needles.

Taste: The palate matches the nose with oak, vanilla, and caramel notes with the addition of dark fruits like cherry and plum.

Finish: The finish is short to medium in length. The aftertaste is smooth with very little burn, yet much like Chandler in Friends during Thanksgiving, slight bitterness popping up at the end.

Opinion: I had heard good things about this bourbon from several people, but only tonight for a friend’s birthday did I finally pick up a bottle. Man, this bourbon sets a standard for budget bourbon! It was really tasty, really affordable, wasn't boring, and everyone at the party drank it neat and enjoyed it! I would highly recommend it to anyone! Buffalo Trace, well done and keep up the good work! Sláinte!
Great for whiskey & coke, not much else. That being said, if this is a drink you make regularly, I highly recommend this bottle over other $10 or less bourbons.
Overall not much happening with this bourbon in terms of depth or complexity. The price point makes it a great cocktail bourbon.

Nose- Acetone and young corn notes. 
Body- More young grain notes. There is a little vanilla and a floral honeysuckle but damn BT. I wouldn’t put my name on this bottle. Damn! 
Finish- Raw grain and bitterness. There is a cigar smoke aftertaste following.

It can get you buzzed so .5 star!
A smooth sipping bourbon that also mixes well
Floral, sweet, not much wood spice
A tasty, sweet 80 proof bourbon. Same mash bill as Buffalo Trace, but younger and lower proof.
Pretty simple beverage which is quite smooth; better neat than with rocks. I'd suggest this would be a very acceptable home well bottle.
Guilty pleasure. I’m not supposed to like this because it’s dirt cheap but for me it’s smoother than it’s big brother Buffalo Trace. Not disappointed if this is the house bourbon
For $9, this a nice, soft balanced pour. Given the bloodline of Buffalo Trace, it’s a great, affordable gem.
Make a great bourbon and coke. Average flavor but nothing that stands out.

At its price point, great value. not much complexity, but solid bourbon flavors. cherry sweetness on the palate. 

for a 12 and under, damn I'm broke bottle, this is probably a headliner.
Only because I enjoy the better Buffalo Trace products. This is for my non bourbon drinkers who want to mix or are loaded...they are not drinking my others...lol...cook with this one also😋
Baby version of buffalo trace - same mash bill . Less rich than buffalo . Larry - “tastes watered down...but it’s good! Hahah”
Mineral sweetness.  Good for a relaxing drink that you don’t want to over-analyze.

Well, for $9.99/bottle, I expect:  rot-gut, off notes, chemical and alcohol after taste, not to mention fake smoke undertones.  I did not find any of these.  After following the recommendation of Distiller members that I believe in, I picked a bottle up to make BBQ sauce with.  I did sample it prior to make sure I was not ruining a sauce.  I was surprised. It is no Blanton's, nor even Buffalo Trace's little brother.  However, it had floral sweetness, notes of vanilla and slight spice.  At 40% ABV, it's a neat dram, or a great base for mixing or highballs. It has now replaced Early Times as my sauce whiskey.  I know it only received a 70/100 from the pro evaluation, but I think I have spent lots more for much lesser pours. 2.75 stars
Not much complexity but an easy sipper at an incredible price.
Fairly shallow with a bit of a sharpness at the start. Leathery, wood and kind of a short finish.
Spicy, a little boozey but for 10 bucks it is more than worth the price tag.  Competes with some 30 dollar bourbons

This is a young Buffalo Trace.  If you like BT, this is a quaint tangent.  I honestly like this better than BT and it's less expensive.  Don't fear the bottom shelf - there are some great finds lurking there.

Smooth. Some oak and sweetness. Not at all complex. Just kind of average. Price considered this is a great value. Good for mixed drinks. 

1.75L
A tasty bourbon. Vanilla and Rye fight for the Dominion, with a draw as outcome. Nice fruity aftertaste. Great stuff for its price tag
Sweet honey, a touch of spice. Some tea notes.

Nose has slight alcohol aroma of a young bourbon. Sweet taste, minimal caramel/vanilla with some spice.  Goes down smooth with slight heat on the end.  For price point, this is a quality bourbon.  I can see how it ends up as Eagle Rare and would certainly be a great fit for cocktails.  Could drink even drink this straight
Great mixer. Luv it with Mountain Dew!!  “Finchy Dew”
It’s a well bourbon.  Young and hot and unrefined but it’s still got its place in the world. Great for cocktails

There’s a bit of a sherry smell to it, and lemon. 

Dry wine and pepper. 

Pepper and oats in the finish.
Rubbery cinnamon smell. Sip 1: watery odd taste. I can’t decide if it tastes like shitty powder flavoring covered popcorn or body odor. Sip 2: more of the same. I can’t finish it.
Cheap, weaker buffalo trace flavors, easy drinker

A solid rot-gut. $9.99 what more are you looking for. I did notice that after letting the bottle breathe for a few days really opened up the nose and palate, smooth for shooting or mixing. Excellent with Coke. Nose of leather dark cherry and molasses, palate smooth maple, vanilla and the slightest burn. 3 stars
This one belongs under the kitchen sink
Bland, no smell; lacks an experience
Smoother than I thought, not much burn. Not a ton of depth of flavor, but some hints of caramel and leather for sure. On a smoked ice cube it’s damn fine.
Pretty smooth. This is my everyday, inexpensive (mixer) bourbon.
never said this before but this is undrinkable. 0/5 utterly disgusting.
Quite possibly the best bang for the buck on the bottom shelf. May be an “entry level” Bourbon, but for flavor and smoothness it is hard to beat at twice the price
Nice taste for a bourbon.  Little bit of a scotch taste to it ... peat/iodine.  For the cost, very enjoyable!

Honey, maple sweetness on the nose which translates little to the pallet. Was still my favorite at a cheap bourbon blind taste test. Medium feel not too complex, finishes just the right amount of heat for my taste.  Not complex but doesn’t pretend to be.  This young bourbon will be good to keep stocked for campfire BS time.

Since I’ve picked up a few bottom feeders, I thought I’d pick up this Buffalo Trace family variant to see how it compares to the other bottom shelfers. I didn’t notice until I got home but it’s actually a Liter. I rarely see that size.
As a reminder that my tasting notes on these a fairly subtle, but this is what I picked up.

On the nose I get that Buffalo Trace dark fruit note along with some baking spices, vanilla and a hint of rye.

The palate is light, which I would expect at 80 proof. I get a continuation of the nose with the sweet dark fruit dominating.

The flavors in the finish are gone pretty quickly, with just a mouth tingly light burn that last for a little bit.

Really not bad. I prefer this to some other bottom shelfers that I’ve tried recently including Old Charter 8, and Heaven Hill Old Style (white label)

The best mixer for the price.  Smooth, no bite

-Cheers

Nose: vanilla, citrus and honey 

Taste: light and sweet. Caramel and light smoke

Finish: thin with almost no burn 

Not bad for a budget bourbon. Makes a very weak old fashioned.
Not bad for a $10 bottle of bourbon.
Sweet artificial cherry. Thin as water. The nicest thing I can say about this is that it doesn’t taste bad. The most honest thing I can say is it’s an embarrassment to BT Distillery.
Not complex and the finish is short but surprisingly tasty for the price.
Not spicy or complicated, but sweet and drinkable. It tastes very good, but it might not be what you want at that time
The best sub $12 bourbon I have found.
This isn't anything to write home about. Frankly, I can't believe I'm taking the time to write about it here. Not enough heat for a cocktail, not enough flavor for neat. Relatively boring.
Smooth, caramel corn and toasted oats. A little plastic on the back of the finish.
Harsh on the nose at first but opened up nicely after a bit. Thin, lighter in color, basic bourbon notes bit nothing special here. but for the price it’s surprisingly decent for sipping on
Favorite mixing bourbon. Not recommended neat

Nose: cherry and sweet, sweet grain. Palate: candy syrup sweetness. So sweet as to almost be off-putting were it not for a slight spiciness and alcohol burn. This bourbon tastes good, but not in the way a bourbon should taste good. It’s too simple and it brings very little to the table other thanks sweetness. Still, you won’t hate it.

Vanilla, honey and sugary sweet candy with a gentle sniff but you can also get the spices, lignins, tannins and a bit of like a dry jasmine or black tea.

Very smooth flowing of sugary goodness into your palate and those extra bit of wood interaction against the new charred American Oak still remind at the bottom of the golden liquid so it's not overpowering the sugary bits.
After you devour the liquid the American Oak attributes started to show up and you also get stuff like leather.

Its a medium finish to short finish that you still get your sugary icing on top.

This is a sweet bourbon that you and your friends can enjoy without whisky been the topic.
Way too underrated. Cannot beat it for the price, always keep a bottle on hand.

Very butterscotch nose, like the butterscotch candies in my great grandmother's candy bowl... palate is spicy sweet, with a slightly bitter "jamocha" shake" finish... so very unique from anything else I've ever tasted
If Busch beer was a whiskey.

Nose definitely indicates it's a Buffalo Trace product... Sweet and spicy with some soft vanilla. Takes me back to walking through the rickhouse on the tour. Sweet and silky on the palate with a little rye spice balanced nicely with the oak. I'm definitely going to try this side by side with Buffalo Trace as it just seems to scream, young or watered down Buffalo Trace.

I know a lot of people make cocktails with this, but I don't feel like it has enough depth and isn't bold enough to hold up well in a cocktail like a Manhattan or Old Fashioned. But... if you want your bitters or garnish to stand out a bit more, this is a nice Buffalo Trace alternative at less than half the price.
So one dimensional and tasteless. Would not recommend.

Nose:   Actually very pleasant   At first I couldn’t identify, but in reading other’s tasting notes I came across one that said reminded him of his grandmother’s butterscotch candy jar.  He nailed it.  That’s exactly what you get - sweet, smooth, butterscotch candy.  

Palate: Flat.  Not a whole lot there.  Very faint black pepper and oak, but overall not a lot of taste.  Surprisingly it coats the mouth well. 

Finish: Finish is actually pretty good considering lack of taste.  Finishes with a sweet burn - a Kentucky hug I suppose.   

Overall, not great, but not bad.  Will be on my shelf for friends who like to mix with a coke, but can’t see it being used for much else as long as I can remain employed.  Very much worth $10 though.
Sweet. Good taste., falls off quick. Small bite, small hug

Nose - Werther’s candy, corn, sweet, thick
Mouth - thin with more Werther’s
Finish - short and sweet, but otherwise uneventful

Nose is the best part, good mixer, would drink straight if nothing else around, but I’d be afraid of getting a headache because of how sweet it is.
Best everyday bourbon on the market
This has a strange after taste. It’s sweet and has a hint of mint and that’s it

I wanted to give this one a fair shot so I did a couple blind taste tests. Unfortunately it got last place twice. Having said that, I do not dislike this bourbon, it just it not a go to by any means. The fact that this bottle was found for a whopping 10$ adds some value. The bottle and label are ugly and the bourbon is just so so.
straight and strong with peaty oak taste. Great for cocktails and affordable
Oaky nasal, not very full bodied. Sweet aftertaste but not much flavor.
3,4 somtimes i smell apple like notes , smooth delicate nice, for this age
Very good for an everyday bourbon very cheap

Nose: corn, vanilla, caramel. Barrel char. Nothing offensive but very light to non existent nose.
Palate: sweet corn and barrel char.... not much else.
Finish: slightly spicy but short.

Overall for A budget pour its not bad. Just corn Oak and spice..... nothing special.
Low Price. Good to have on hand for mixed drinks. Very sweet tasting.
Not much going on here. Rather flat. Buy Evan Williams Black for some taste.
Not bad. Sweet and a little spice on the finish.

Butterscotch and vanilla in your face on the nose, maybe even some vanilla cream cheese white cake? Taste doesn't hold up to the nose, though. Sweet but goes away almost immediately leading to a tongue and front of the mouth coating spiciness that seems to last a lot longer than what one would expect from such a low cost bourbon. Not on par with say an OGD spiciness but it's noticeable.
